data.title: France's Financial Markets Now Unfazed by Mitterrand
data.text:
When Socialist candidates win big in Europe, stock markets usually nose-dive, but the Paris Bourse bucked that historical tide and rose strongly today, the day after France's Socialist President, Francois Mitterrand, won election to a new seven-year term.

What is more, the French franc -which many economists feared might plunge following a Mitterrand victory - rose slightly against both the dollar and the West German mark in European trading today. Later, in New York, the franc was up slightly against the dollar and down a bit against the mark.

It was a far cry from 1981, when the French stock market fell 20 percent in two days and the franc plummeted after Mr. Mitterrand's election. At that time, he ran on a joint platform with the Communist Party that called for sweeping nationalizations and a huge increase in social spending.

''Seven years ago the Socialists proposed a new type of society and put into question the free-market policies we lived under,'' said Thierry Huon, an analyst with Rondeleux Oudart, a French brokerage. ''Today, however, the stock market didn't fall because President Mitterrand has not promised much to his Socialist backers except to impose a tax on great fortunes.''

From 1981 to 1983, Mr. Mitterrand's Government adopted a go-it-alone radical program of nationalizations and pump-priming that aimed to reduce France's unemployment rate, which remains high to this day. That strategy led to inflationary pressures and trade-deficit problems and ultimately to a crisis of confidence for the franc.

In response, Mr. Mitterrand's Government took a distinct right turn -to the dismay of his left-wing supporters. His economic approach went from being Socialist to being Social Democrat as it began focusing more on reducing inflation and encouraging investment.
